Package com.github.mjstewart.querystring.expression

Class QueryStringHelper

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.github.mjstewart.querystring.expression.QueryStringHelper

  • public final class QueryStringHelper
extends Object
    Provides public methods exposed to the thymeleaf template caller.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method Description
      String add​(String queryString, String key, String value)
      Adds the given key and value to the end of the query string with the value being escaped to form a valid query string.
      String addAll​(String queryString, List<List<String>> keyValuePairs)
      Behaves exactly like add(String, String, String) except adds many key value pairs to the end of the query string in the exact order they are provided.
      String adjustFirstNumericValueBy​(String queryString, String key, int value)
      Functions the same as adjustNumericValueBy(String, String, List, int) except only updates the first occurrence of the numeric key value.
      String adjustNumericValueBy​(String queryString, String key, List<Integer> relativeIndexes, int value)
      Adds the supplied value to a range of numerical key values identified by relative index.
      String createNewSort​(String queryString, List<String> fieldAndDirections)
      Removes all existing sort keys and associates the supplied field and sort direction values to a sort key which gets appended to the end of the query string.
      String decrementPage​(String queryString)
      Decrements the value for key 'page' by 1 providing the value is numeric otherwise there is no effect.
      Function<String,String> fieldSorterAsc​(String queryString)
      Returns a function accepting a sort field applying sorting logic according to the below scenarios.
      Function<String,String> fieldSorterDesc​(String queryString)
      See fieldSorterAsc(String) since this method is the same except returns a function capable of sorting a field having a default sort direction of desc.
      List<String> getAllValues​(String queryString, String key)
      Gets all value associated with the the given key.
      String getCurrentSortDirectionAsc​(String queryString, String field)
      Extracts the field from the queryString if it appears as a sort field and returns its current sort direction.
      String getCurrentSortDirectionDesc​(String queryString, String field)
      The same as getCurrentSortDirectionAsc(String, String) except this method uses desc as the fallback when the sort field contains no explicit sort direction.
      String getFirstValue​(String queryString, String key)
      Gets the value associated with the first occurrence of the given key.
      String incrementPage​(String queryString)
      Increments the value for key 'page' by 1 providing the value is numeric otherwise there is no effect.
      String incrementPage​(String queryString, int maxBound)
      The same as incrementPage(String) except only increments the existing value if it is below the maxBound.
      boolean isFieldSorted​(String queryString, String field)
      Checks if the supplied field appears as a sort field.
      String removeAll​(String queryString, List<String> keys)
      Removes every key and their associated values should the key exist while maintaining the query strings original order.
      String removeAllAndAdd​(String queryString, List<String> removeKeys, List<List<String>> addKeyValuePairs)
      Convenience method to remove all occurrences of a list of keys followed by adding a list of new key value pairs.
      String removeAnyKeyMatchingValue​(String queryString, String valueMatch)
      Similar to removeKeyMatchingValue(String, String, String) except no target key is provided causing all keys to be eligible for removal if the value matches.
      String removeFirst​(String queryString, String key)
      Removes the first occurrence of the supplied key while maintaining the query strings original order.
      String removeKeyMatchingValue​(String queryString, String key, String valueMatch)
      Removes the target key if its value is equal to the matching value by using case insensitive equality.
      String removeManyNth​(String queryString, String key, List<Integer> relativeIndexes)
      Applies the same logic as removeNth(String, String, int) except provides the ability to remove multiple relative indexes at the same time.
      String removeN​(String queryString, String key, int n)
      The same concept as dropN in functional languages where the first n occurrences of the target key are removed while maintaining the query strings original order.
      String removeNth​(String queryString, String key, int nthIndex)
      Removes the nth relative index of the given key while maintaining the query strings original order.
      String removeNthAndAdd​(String queryString, Map<String,List<Integer>> removeInstructions, List<List<String>> addKeyValuePairs)
      Convenience method to perform a removeNth(String, String, int) on many unique keys while maintaining the original query strings ordering.
      String replaceFirst​(String queryString, String key, String value)
      Replaces only the first occurrence of key with value while maintaining the query strings original order.
      String replaceN​(String queryString, String key, List<String> values)
      Replaces the first N values associated with the key while maintaining the query strings original order.
      String replaceNth​(String queryString, Map<String,Map<Integer,String>> stateChangeInstructions)
      Replaces the nth key with the supplied value based on a keys relative index while maintaining the query strings original order.
      String setSortDirectionAsc​(String queryString, String sortField)
      Finds a 'sort' key having a value equal to sortField which is to be changed to asc.
      String setSortDirectionDesc​(String queryString, String sortField)
      See setSortDirectionAsc(String, String) as this method simply changes the sort field to direction desc.
      String toggleSortDefaultAsc​(String queryString, String sortField)
      Finds a 'sort' key having a value equal to sortField which is to have its sort direction toggled to its opposite.
      String toggleSortDefaultDesc​(String queryString, String sortField)
      Works the same as toggleSortDefaultAsc(String, String) except applies the default sort direction 'desc'.
      String url​(String requestURI, String queryString)
      Concatenates the request uri with the query string should it exist.
      Function<String,String> urlBuilder​(String requestURI)
      See url(String, String) for docs as this method is provided out of convenience to clean up thymeleaf template code to avoid having to supply the #request.getRequestURI() each time.
      Function<String,String> valueWhenMatchesSortAsc​(String queryString, String missingValue, String matchingValue, String nonMatchingValue)
      This method is useful for conditional css classes or tooltips where different values should be returned based on the current sort direction.
      Function<String,String> valueWhenMatchesSortDesc​(String queryString, String missingValue, String matchingValue, String nonMatchingValue)
      The same as valueWhenMatchesSortAsc(String, String, String, String) except applies the opposite logic for 'desc' direction.

      • QueryStringHelper

        public QueryStringHelper​()

    • Method Detail

      • replaceFirst

        public String replaceFirst​(String queryString,
                           String key,
                           String value)
        Replaces only the first occurrence of key with value while maintaining the query strings original order.

        Thymeleaf usage

             #request.getQueryString() = "suburb=west®ion=AU&postcode=494849"

     th:with="newQueryString=${#qs.replaceFirst(#request.getQueryString(), 'region', 'Australia')}"
     => newQueryString = "suburb=west®ion=Australia&postcode=494849"

        Supplying a null or empty queryString will return an empty string. All other arguments must receive valid values otherwise the behaviour is undefined.

        Parameters:
        queryString - The current query string.
        key - The target key to replace the value for.
        value - The replacement value.
        Returns:
        The new query string.

      • replaceNth

        public String replaceNth​(String queryString,
                         Map<String,Map<Integer,String>> stateChangeInstructions)
        Replaces the nth key with the supplied value based on a keys relative index while maintaining the query strings original order.

        Thymeleaf usage

        region can be thought of as having an array of 3 values. 

                 region = ['AU', 'Australia', 'AUS']
        region[1], region[2] are replaced with the new values of 'Auckland' and 'AUKL' respectively while while region[0] remains unchanged. 
             #request.getQueryString() = "region=AU&suburb=west&region=Australia&postcode=494849&region=AUS"

     th:with="newQueryString=${#qs.replaceNth(#request.getQueryString(), {region: { 1: 'Auckland', 2: 'AUKL' }})}"
     newQueryString = "region=AU&suburb=west&region=Auckland&postcode=494849&region=AUKL"

        Supplying a null or empty queryString will return an empty string. The syntax for the stateChangeInstructions Map must be exactly as the example shows, otherwise there will be casting errors.

        Parameters:
        queryString - The current query string.
        stateChangeInstructions - A map containing the instructions on how to modify the query string.
        Returns:
        The new query string.

      • replaceN

        public String replaceN​(String queryString,
                       String key,
                       List<String> values)
        Replaces the first N values associated with the key while maintaining the query strings original order.

        Consider the query string "name=john&age=30&name=joseph&month=march&name=smith"

        The key 'name' can be visualised as an array containing 3 values. 

                 name = ['john', 'joseph', 'smith']

        The thymeleaf usage example shows 2 values being provided ['mary', 'rose'] which replace the existing 2 values in the corresponding index positions while leaving the last index of 'smith' unchanged. The transformation is equivalent to

             name = ['john', 'joseph', 'smith']
     name[0] = 'mary'
     name[1] = 'rose'

        If 1 value was provided, only the first value would be replaced, whereas if 100 values were provided then all 3 would be replaced by the first 3 corresponding replacement values.

        Thymeleaf usage

             #request.getQueryString() = "name=john&age=30&name=joseph&month=march&name=smith"

     th:with="newQueryString=${#qs.replaceN(#request.getQueryString(), 'name', {'mary', 'rose'})}"
     => newQueryString = "name=mary&age=30&name=rose&month=march&name=smith"

        Supplying a null or empty queryString will return an empty string. All other arguments must receive valid values otherwise the behaviour is undefined.

        Parameters:
        queryString - The current query string.
        key - The target key to replace the corresponding values for.
        values - The replacement values, eg values[0] will replace the keys value at index 0 in the query string.
        Returns:
        The new query string.

      • removeFirst

        public String removeFirst​(String queryString,
                          String key)
        Removes the first occurrence of the supplied key while maintaining the query strings original order.
        Thymeleaf usage
        #request.getQueryString() = "name=john&age=30&name=joseph&month=march&name=smith"

        All keys are unique
        If all keys are unique, this method simply removes the key 
             th:with="newQueryString=${#qs.removeFirst(#request.getQueryString(), 'age')}"
     => newQueryString = "name=john&name=joseph&month=march&name=smith" (age completely gone).
        Duplicate keys
        When there are duplicate keys such as 'name' containing 3 values ['john', 'joseph', 'smith']. The effect of calling removeFirst is simply removing name[0]. 
             th:with="newQueryString=${#qs.removeFirst(#request.getQueryString(), 'name')}"
     => newQueryString = "age=30&name=joseph&month=march&name=smith" (other names still remain)

        Supplying a null or empty queryString will return an empty string. All other arguments must receive valid values otherwise the behaviour is undefined.

        Parameters:
        queryString - The current query string.
        key - The target key to remove.
        Returns:
        The new query string.

      • removeAll

        public String removeAll​(String queryString,
                        List<String> keys)
        Removes every key and their associated values should the key exist while maintaining the query strings original order.

        The example shows removing keys ['region', 'postcode'] with the resulting query string containing the remaining keys 'suburb' and 'language' in the order they originally appeared.

        Thymeleaf usage

             #request.getQueryString() = "region=AU&suburb=west®ion=Australia&postcode=494849®ion=AUS&language=en"

     th:with="newQueryString=${#qs.removeAll(#request.getQueryString(), {'region', 'postcode'})}"
     => newQueryString = "suburb=west&language=en"

        Supplying a null or empty queryString will return an empty string. The syntax for the list of keys must be exactly as the example shows, otherwise there will be casting errors

        Parameters:
        queryString - The current query string.
        keys - The keys to remove.
        Returns:
        The new query string.

      • removeN

        public String removeN​(String queryString,
                      String key,
                      int n)
        The same concept as dropN in functional languages where the first n occurrences of the target key are removed while maintaining the query strings original order.

        Using the thymeleaf usage example, the key 'name' can be visualised as an array containing 3 values. name = ['john', 'joseph', 'smith'].

        removeN will simply delete the first n values as shown below.

             n=-1 -> ['john', 'joseph', 'smith'] (invalid n has no effect).
     n=0 -> ['john', 'joseph', 'smith'] (dropping nothing has no effect).
     n=1 -> ['joseph', 'smith']
     n=2 -> ['smith']
     n=3 -> []
     n=100 -> []

        Thymeleaf usage

        The example removes the 'name' keys first 2 values with 'smith' still remaining.

             #request.getQueryString() = "name=john&age=30&name=joseph&month=march&name=smith"

     th:with="newQueryString=${#qs.removeN(#request.getQueryString(), 'name', 2)}"
     => newQueryString = "age=30&month=march&name=smith"

        Supplying a null or empty queryString will return an empty string. All other arguments must receive valid values otherwise the behaviour is undefined.

        Parameters:
        queryString - The current query string.
        key - The key to drop n values from.
        n - How many keys to remove.
        Returns:
        The new query string.

      • removeNth

        public String removeNth​(String queryString,
                        String key,
                        int nthIndex)
        Removes the nth relative index of the given key while maintaining the query strings original order. The concept of relative index is outlined below using the 'name' key as the target. 
             "name=john&age=30&name=joseph&month=march&name=smith"

               0        1         2      (relative indexes)
     name = ['john', 'joseph', 'smith']

        Thymeleaf usage

        The example demonstrates removing the middle name at index 1.

             #request.getQueryString() = "name=john&age=30&name=joseph&month=march&name=smith"

     th:with="newQueryString=${#qs.removeNth(#request.getQueryString(), 'name', 1)}"
     => newQueryString = "name=john&age=30&month=march&name=smith"

        Supplying a null or empty queryString will return an empty string. All other arguments must receive valid values otherwise the behaviour is undefined.

        Parameters:
        queryString - The current query string.
        key - The target key.
        nthIndex - The relative index to remove for the given key.
        Returns:
        The new query string.

      • removeManyNth

        public String removeManyNth​(String queryString,
                            String key,
                            List<Integer> relativeIndexes)
        Applies the same logic as removeNth(String, String, int) except provides the ability to remove multiple relative indexes at the same time. The below example shows how its possible to remove relative indexes 0 and 2 while keeping the middle name 'joseph'. 
             "name=john&age=30&name=joseph&month=march&name=smith"

               0        1         2      (relative indexes)
     name = ['john', 'joseph', 'smith']

        Thymeleaf usage

             #request.getQueryString() = "name=john&age=30&name=joseph&month=march&name=smith"

     th:with="newQueryString=${#qs.removeManyNth(#request.getQueryString(), 'name', {0, 2})}"
     => "age=30&name=joseph&month=march"

        Supplying a null or empty queryString will return an empty string. The syntax for the list of relativeIndexes must be exactly as the example shows, otherwise there will be casting errors. All other arguments must receive valid values otherwise the behaviour is undefined.

        Parameters:
        queryString - The current query string.
        key - The target key.
        relativeIndexes - The relative indexes to remove for the given key.
        Returns:
        The new query string.

      • removeKeyMatchingValue

        public String removeKeyMatchingValue​(String queryString,
                                     String key,
                                     String valueMatch)
        Removes the target key if its value is equal to the matching value by using case insensitive equality. The example shows that for the target key 'region', only remove the key if the value is equal to 'australia'. Note the case insensitivity. Use {#link removeAnyKeyMatchingValue(String, String)} if any key matching the value should be removed rather than a specific target key.

        Thymeleaf usage

             #request.getQueryString() = "region=AU®ion=south®ion=AUSTRALIA&sort=country,asc"

     th:with="newQueryString=${#qs.removeKeyMatchingValue(#request.getQueryString(), 'region', 'australia')}"
     => newQueryString = "region=AU®ion=south&sort=country,asc"

        Supplying a null or empty queryString will return an empty string. All other arguments must receive valid values otherwise the behaviour is undefined.

        Parameters:
        queryString - The current query string.
        key - The target key.
        valueMatch - The case insensitive value to match which triggers deletion.
        Returns:
        The new query string.

      • removeAnyKeyMatchingValue

        public String removeAnyKeyMatchingValue​(String queryString,
                                        String valueMatch)
        Similar to removeKeyMatchingValue(String, String, String) except no target key is provided causing all keys to be eligible for removal if the value matches. Case insensitive equality applies.

        Thymeleaf usage

        The example shows any key matching the value 'australia' (case insensitive) will be removed.

             #request.getQueryString() = "region=AU&region=south&region=AUSTRALIA&sort=country,asc&locale=australia"

     th:with="newQueryString=${#qs.removeAnyKeyMatchingValue(#request.getQueryString(), 'australia')}"
     => newQueryString = "region=AU&region=south&sort=country,asc"

        Supplying a null or empty queryString will return an empty string. All other arguments must receive valid values otherwise the behaviour is undefined.

        Parameters:
        queryString - The current query string.
        valueMatch - The case insensitive value to match which triggers deletion.
        Returns:
        The new query string.

      • getFirstValue

        public String getFirstValue​(String queryString,
                            String key)
        Gets the value associated with the first occurrence of the given key. Use getAllValues(String, String) if there are duplicate keys and require all values to be returned.
        Thymeleaf usage
        #request.getQueryString() = "name=john&age=30&name=joseph&month=march&name=smith"

        All keys are unique
        If all keys are unique, the single value associated to the key is returned 
             th:with="newQueryString=${#qs.getFirstValue(#request.getQueryString(), 'age')}"
     => "30"
        Duplicate keys
        If there are duplicate keys such as 'name' with values ['john', 'joseph', 'smith'] then getFirstValue returns name[0] 
             th:with="newQueryString=${#qs.getFirstValue(#request.getQueryString(), 'name')}"
     => "john"
        Key not found
        If no key is found, null is returned. 
             th:with="newQueryString=${#qs.getFirstValue(#request.getQueryString(), 'city')}"
     => null

        Supplying a null or empty queryString will return an empty string. All other arguments must receive valid values otherwise the behaviour is undefined.

        Parameters:
        queryString - The current query string.
        key - The key to get the value for.
        Returns:
        The associated value or null if the key does not exist.

      • getAllValues

        public List<String> getAllValues​(String queryString,
                                 String key)
        Gets all value associated with the the given key.
        Thymeleaf usage
        #request.getQueryString() = "name=john&age=30&name=joseph&month=march&name=smith"

        All keys are unique
        The returned list will contain the single value associated to the key 
             th:with="newQueryString=${#qs.getAllValues(#request.getQueryString(), 'age')}"
     => ["30"]
        Duplicate keys
        If there are duplicate keys such as 'name' with values ['john', 'joseph', 'smith'], all 3 values are returned in a list 
             th:with="newQueryString=${#qs.getAllValues(#request.getQueryString(), 'name')}"
     => ["john", "joseph", "smith"]
        Key not found
        If no key is found, an empty list is returned. 
            th:with="newQueryString=${#qs.getAllValues(#request.getQueryString(), 'city')}"
     => []

        Supplying a null or empty queryString will return an empty list. All other arguments must receive valid values otherwise the behaviour is undefined.

        Parameters:
        queryString - The current query string.
        key - The key to get the values for.
        Returns:
        The associated values or any empty list if the key does not exist.

      • add

        public String add​(String queryString,
                  String key,
                  String value)
        Adds the given key and value to the end of the query string with the value being escaped to form a valid query string.
        Thymeleaf usage
        #request.getQueryString() = "name=john&age=30"

        New key
        A new key and its value is added to the end. Notice how the white space has been escaped. 
             th:with="newQueryString=${#qs.add(#request.getQueryString(), 'city', 'san francisco')}"
     => newQueryString = name=john&age=30&city=san%20francisco
        Key and value exists
        If exactly the same key and value exist, the original query string is returned unmodified. 
             th:with="newQueryString=${#qs.add(#request.getQueryString(), 'name', 'john')}"
     => newQueryString = name=john&age=30
        Same key but different value
        If same key but different value is added, the new key and value pair is added to the end resulting in 2 of the same keys having different values. 
             th:with="newQueryString=${#qs.add(#request.getQueryString(), 'name', 'smith')}"
     => newQueryString = name=john&age=30&name=smith
        null or empty query string
        If the query string is null or empty, the key and value will form the new query string. 
             th:with="newQueryString=${#qs.add(null, 'city', 'melbourne')}"
     => newQueryString = city=melbourne

        Supplying a null or empty queryString will return the new key and value in query string form. All other arguments must receive valid values otherwise the behaviour is undefined.

        Parameters:
        queryString - The current query string.
        key - The key.
        value - The value to associate to the key.
        Returns:
        The new query string.

      • addAll

        public String addAll​(String queryString,
                     List<List<String>> keyValuePairs)
        Behaves exactly like add(String, String, String) except adds many key value pairs to the end of the query string in the exact order they are provided. If the key/value pair already exists, it is ignored.
        Thymeleaf usage
        The example shows adding 2 new key/value pairs (city='san francisco' and country='US') while ignoring name='john' since it already exists. 
             #request.getQueryString() = "name=john&age=30"

     th:with="newQueryString=${#qs.addAll(#request.getQueryString(), {{'city', 'san francisco'}, {'country', 'US'}, {'name', 'john'}})}"
     => name=john&age=30&city=san%20francisco&country=US

        The syntax for the 2d list of keyValuePairs must be exactly as the example shows, otherwise there will be casting errors. If the query string is null or empty, all key value pairs will be joined to form the new query string.

        Parameters:
        queryString - The current query string.
        keyValuePairs - The list of key value pairs to add to the end of the query string if it does not exist.
        Returns:
        The new query string.

      • removeAllAndAdd

        public String removeAllAndAdd​(String queryString,
                              List<String> removeKeys,
                              List<List<String>> addKeyValuePairs)
        Convenience method to remove all occurrences of a list of keys followed by adding a list of new key value pairs.

        This method is a useful alternative to executing a replace. Sometimes its not known the exact format of the query string so it is easier to simply remove 1 or many keys followed by adding the new key/value pairs.

        Thymeleaf usage

        The example demonstrates removing all occurrences of the 'postcode' and 'sort' keys. The key 'sort' is then re-added to the end of the query string with a value of 'city,desc'. When using spring PagingAndSortingRepository, the primary sort field is defined first followed by secondary sort keys. The example changes the secondary sort key of 'city' to be the new primary sort field. 

             #request.getQueryString() = "sort=country,asc&sort=city,desc&location=AU&region=north&postcode=4931495"

     th:with="newQueryString=${#qs.removeAllAndAdd(#request.getQueryString(), {'postcode', 'sort'}, {{'sort', 'city,desc'}})}"
     => location=AU&region=north&sort=city,desc

        The syntax for the list arguments must be exactly as the example shows, otherwise there will be casting errors. If the query string is null or empty, all new key value pairs will be joined to form the new query string.

        Parameters:
        queryString - The current query string.
        removeKeys - The keys to remove.
        addKeyValuePairs - The new key value pairs to add to the end of the query string.
        Returns:
        The new query string.

      • removeNthAndAdd

        public String removeNthAndAdd​(String queryString,
                              Map<String,List<Integer>> removeInstructions,
                              List<List<String>> addKeyValuePairs)
        Convenience method to perform a removeNth(String, String, int) on many unique keys while maintaining the original query strings ordering. After the removal, the list of key value pairs are added to the end of the query string.
        Thymeleaf usage

        The example shows key 'sort' having values ['country,asc', 'city,desc'] and key 'region' with values ['north, 'upper', 'border'].

        The removal step has the effect of deleting sort[0] and region[1], region[2]. After the removal, 2 new key value pairs (postcode=39481 and locale=AU) are added to the end of the query string.

             #request.getQueryString() = "sort=country,asc&sort=city,desc&location=AU&region=north&region=upper&region=border"

     th:with="newQueryString=${#qs.removeNthAndAdd(#request.getQueryString(), {'sort': {0}, 'region': {1, 2}}, {{'postcode', '39481'}, {'locale', 'AU'}})}"
     => newQueryString = sort=city,desc&location=AU&region=north&postcode=39481&locale=AU

        The syntax for the removeInstructions and addKeyValuePairs must be exactly as the example shows, otherwise there will be casting errors. If the query string is null or empty, all new key value pairs will be joined to form the new query string.

        Parameters:
        queryString - The current query string.
        removeInstructions - The keys and corresponding relative value indexes to remove.
        addKeyValuePairs - The new key value pairs to add to the end of the query string.
        Returns:
        The new query string.

      • adjustNumericValueBy

        public String adjustNumericValueBy​(String queryString,
                                   String key,
                                   List<Integer> relativeIndexes,
                                   int value)
        Adds the supplied value to a range of numerical key values identified by relative index. Decrementing a value can be achieved by supplying a negative number. Consider alternative methods such as adjustFirstNumericValueBy or incrementPage if a specific key is being targeted.
        Thymeleaf usage

        The example shows key 'policy' having values [10, 20, 30]. Lets assume we want to add 5 to only the values at index 1 and 2. The result is the last 2 values being incremented by 5 while the first value remains unchanged at 10.

             #request.getQueryString() = "policy=10&sort=country&policy=20&location=AU&border=north&policy=30"

     th:with="newQueryString=${#qs.adjustNumericValueBy(#request.getQueryString(), 'policy', {1, 2}, 5)}"
     => newQueryString = policy=10&sort=country&policy=25&location=AU&border=north&policy=35

        The syntax for the relativeIndexes must be exactly as the example shows, otherwise there will be casting errors. Supplying a null or empty queryString will return an empty string. All other arguments must receive valid values otherwise the behaviour is undefined.

        Parameters:
        queryString - The current query string.
        key - The target key to find numeric values for.
        relativeIndexes - Which indexes to add the value to.
        value - The value to add (for decrementing use a negative number).
        Returns:
        The new query string.

      • adjustFirstNumericValueBy

        public String adjustFirstNumericValueBy​(String queryString,
                                        String key,
                                        int value)
        Functions the same as adjustNumericValueBy(String, String, List, int) except only updates the first occurrence of the numeric key value. This method is provided for convenience to avoid having to provide the relative index list. To decrement the value, supply a negative number.
        Thymeleaf usage

        The example shows key 'policy' having values [10, 20, 30]. This method only updates index 0 resulting in the first 'policy' key having the new value 12.

             #request.getQueryString() = "policy=10&sort=country&policy=20&location=AU&border=north&policy=30"

     th:with="newQueryString=${#qs.adjustFirstNumericValueBy(#request.getQueryString(), 'policy', 2)}"
     => newQueryString = policy=12&sort=country&policy=20&location=AU&border=north&policy=30

        Supplying a null or empty queryString will return an empty string. All other arguments must receive valid values otherwise the behaviour is undefined.

        Parameters:
        queryString - The current query string.
        key - The target key to find the first numeric value for.
        value - The value to add (for decrementing use a negative number).
        Returns:
        The new query string.

      • incrementPage

        public String incrementPage​(String queryString)
        Increments the value for key 'page' by 1 providing the value is numeric otherwise there is no effect. This method is useful when working with spring PagingAndSortingRepository which uses the key 'page' by convention.

        Use incrementPage(String, int) to provide automatic upper bounds checking to ensure page is not incremented beyond what the PagingAndSortingRepository will provide.

        Thymeleaf usage
           #request.getQueryString() = "city=dallas&country=US&sort=country,desc&page=0"

   th:with="newQueryString=${#qs.incrementPage(#request.getQueryString())}"
   => newQueryString = city=dallas&country=US&sort=country,desc&page=1
        Note:

        Supplying a null or empty queryString will return an empty string.

        Parameters:
        queryString - The current query string.
        Returns:
        The new query string.

      • incrementPage

        public String incrementPage​(String queryString,
                            int maxBound)
        The same as incrementPage(String) except only increments the existing value if it is below the maxBound. This is convenient to use to avoid having to implement additional bounds checking in the template code.
        Thymeleaf usage

        Consider a html table with paging where you would like to prevent the page count from exceeding the total pages available from the PagingAndSortingRepository. The example assumes customers is of type Page<Customer> and is in the Model. If there are 10 total pages, and the current page is 9 representing the last page, setting maxBound = 9 will prevent the page from being incremented.

           th:with="newQueryString=${#qs.incrementPage(#request.getQueryString(), customers.getTotalPages() - 1)}"
        Parameters:
        queryString - The current query string.
        maxBound - Increment current value only if it is below the maxBound.
        Returns:
        The new query string.

      • decrementPage

        public String decrementPage​(String queryString)
        Decrements the value for key 'page' by 1 providing the value is numeric otherwise there is no effect. The value is not decremented below 0 which eliminates the need to do lower bound checking within the thymeleaf template itself. This method is useful when working with spring PagingAndSortingRepository which uses the key 'page' by convention.
        Thymeleaf usage
             #request.getQueryString() = "city=dallas&country=US&sort=country,desc&page=1"

     th:with="newQueryString=${#qs.decrementPage(#request.getQueryString())}"
     => newQueryString = city=dallas&country=US&sort=country,desc&page=0

        Supplying a null or empty queryString will return an empty string.

        Parameters:
        queryString - The current query string.
        Returns:
        The new query string.

      • setSortDirectionAsc

        public String setSortDirectionAsc​(String queryString,
                                  String sortField)
        Finds a 'sort' key having a value equal to sortField which is to be changed to asc. This method is useful when working with spring PagingAndSortingRepository which uses the key 'sort' by convention
        Thymeleaf usage

        The example shows 'country' as not having an explicit sort direction meaning the default direction is determined by the spring repository. Since the setSortDirectionXXX with trailing 'Asc' is used, 'country' is set to direction 'asc'.

             #request.getQueryString() = "city=dallas&country=US&sort=country&page=1"

     th:with="newQueryString=${#qs.setSortDirectionAsc(#request.getQueryString(), 'country')}"
     => newQueryString = city=dallas&country=US&sort=country,asc&page=1
        Note:

        Supplying a null or empty queryString will return an empty string. All other arguments must receive valid values otherwise the behaviour is undefined.

        Parameters:
        queryString - The current query string
        sortField - The sort field to change the sort direction to asc.
        Returns:
        The new query string.

      • setSortDirectionDesc

        public String setSortDirectionDesc​(String queryString,
                                   String sortField)
        See setSortDirectionAsc(String, String) as this method simply changes the sort field to direction desc.
        Parameters:
        queryString - The current query string
        sortField - The sort field to change the sort direction to desc.
        Returns:
        The new query string.

      • toggleSortDefaultAsc

        public String toggleSortDefaultAsc​(String queryString,
                                   String sortField)
        Finds a 'sort' key having a value equal to sortField which is to have its sort direction toggled to its opposite. E.g: 'asc' becomes 'desc' and vice versa. There are 2 variants of this method toggleSortDefaultXXX with trailing 'Asc' or 'Desc'. The trailing direction determines how a sort field with no direction is treated as illustrated in the below examples.
        Thymeleaf usage
        Implicit sort direction
        'country' has no explicit direction implying its default direction is 'asc' since the toggleSortDefaultXXX trailing 'Asc' method is being used. Since the current direction is 'asc', toggling causes the new direction to be 'desc'. 
             #request.getQueryString() = "city=dallas&country=US&sort=country&page=1"

     th:with="newQueryString=${#qs.toggleSortDefaultAsc(#request.getQueryString(), 'country')}"
     => newQueryString = city=dallas&country=US&sort=country,desc&page=1
        Explicit sort direction
        'country' has an explicit direction of 'desc' resulting in the post toggle direction being 'asc'. 
             #request.getQueryString() = "city=dallas&country=US&sort=country,desc&page=1"

     th:with="newQueryString=${#qs.toggleSortDefaultAsc(#request.getQueryString(), 'country')}"
     => newQueryString = city=dallas&country=US&sort=country,asc&page=1

        Supplying a null or empty queryString will return an empty string. All other arguments must receive valid values otherwise the behaviour is undefined.

        Parameters:
        queryString - The current query string
        sortField - The sort field to toggle the sort direction for.
        Returns:
        The new query string.

      • toggleSortDefaultDesc

        public String toggleSortDefaultDesc​(String queryString,
                                    String sortField)
        Works the same as toggleSortDefaultAsc(String, String) except applies the default sort direction 'desc'.
        Thymeleaf usage
        Implicit sort direction
        'country' has no explicit direction implying its default direction is 'desc' since the toggleSortDefaultXXX trailing 'Desc' method is being used. Since the current direction is 'desc', toggling causes the new direction to be 'asc'. 
             #request.getQueryString() = "city=dallas&country=US&sort=country&page=1"

     th:with="newQueryString=${#qs.toggleSortDefaultDesc(#request.getQueryString(), 'country')}"
     => newQueryString = city=dallas&country=US&sort=country,asc&page=1
        Explicit sort direction
        'country' has an explicit direction of 'asc' resulting in the post toggle direction being 'desc'. 
             #request.getQueryString() = "city=dallas&country=US&sort=country,asc&page=1"

     th:with="newQueryString=${#qs.toggleSortDefaultDesc(#request.getQueryString(), 'country')}"
     => newQueryString = city=dallas&country=US&sort=country,desc&page=1
        Note:

        Supplying a null or empty queryString will return an empty string. All other arguments must receive valid values otherwise the behaviour is undefined.

        Parameters:
        queryString - The current query string
        sortField - The sort field to toggle the sort direction for.
        Returns:
        The new query string.

      • fieldSorterAsc

        public Function<String,String> fieldSorterAsc​(String queryString)
        Returns a function accepting a sort field applying sorting logic according to the below scenarios.

        Consider the query string 'sort=suburb,desc', the sort field provided to the returned function would be 'suburb'. A function is returned to allow reuse within the thymeleaf template to avoid needing to provide the query string each time.

        If the field exists in the query string, it is toggled to its opposite direction. Otherwise all existing sort keys are removed with the new sort field 'field,defaultDirection' appended to the end of the new query. 'defaultDirection' is determined by the trailing 'Asc' or 'Desc' in the method name should no explicit direction be provided.

        Thymeleaf Usage
        Query string is null or empty

        Since fieldSorterAsc is used, 'Asc' is the default direction for the sort field 'country'.

            #request.getQueryString() = null

    th:with="newQueryString=${#qs.fieldSorterAsc(#request.getQueryString()).apply('country')}"
    => newQueryString = "sort=country,asc"
        Field exists and has an explicit sort direction

        'country' has current sort direction of asc resulting in the opposite direction of desc after the toggle.

              #request.getQueryString() = "city=melbourne&sort=country,asc&sort=city"

     th:with="newQueryString=${#qs.fieldSorterAsc(#request.getQueryString()).apply('country')}"
     => newQueryString = "city=melbourne&sort=country,desc&sort=city"
        Field exists and has implicit sort direction

        Since fieldSorterAsc is used, 'Asc' is the default direction used by 'city' given there is no explicit direction listed. The means 'city' is toggled to 'desc'.

             #request.getQueryString() = "city=melbourne&sort=country,asc&sort=city"

     th:with="newQueryString=${#qs.fieldSorterAsc(#request.getQueryString()).apply('city')}"
     => newQueryString = "city=melbourne&sort=country,asc&sort=city,desc"
        Field does not exist

        Since 'location' does not exist as a sort field, a new sort key value pair is added to the end of the query string upon removing any existing sorting. Note: the 'Asc' at the end of this method name implies the default sort direction which is why 'location' is set to direction 'asc'.

              #request.getQueryString() = "city=melbourne&sort=country,asc&sort=city"

     th:with="newQueryString=${#qs.fieldSorterAsc(#request.getQueryString()).apply('location')}"
     => newQueryString = "city=melbourne&sort=location,asc"
        How to sort on a nested object?

        Given a Person containing an Address with a suburb, use property dot notation to construct the sort. Note: Person is assumed to exist in the Model available in the thymeleaf template. To reiterate, since 'address.suburb' is not a current sort field, all existing sort fields are removed followed by adding this new sort instruction to the end with default direction 'asc' implied by the trailing 'Asc' in the method name.

              #request.getQueryString() = "city=melbourne&sort=country,asc&sort=city"

     th:with="newQueryString=${#qs.fieldSorterAsc(#request.getQueryString()).apply('address.suburb')}"
     => newQueryString = "city=melbourne&sort=address.suburb,asc"
        Complete example
        It is useful to define variables in a th:with statement to avoid needing to pass in the query string or request URI each time it is used within a th table header for example. 
              
      <table> th:with="qstring=${#request.getQueryString()},
                      urlBuilder=${#qs.urlBuilder(#request.getRequestURI())},
                      fieldSorterAsc=${#qs.fieldSorterAsc(qstring)},
                      fieldSorterDesc=${#qs.fieldSorterDesc(qstring)}"
             <thead>
                <tr>
                  <th th:with="newUrl=${urlBuilder.apply(fieldSorterAsc.apply('name'))}"
                     th:onclick="'javascript:onSortChange(\'' + ${newUrl} + '\');'">
                     Hotel
                  </th>

                  <th th:with="newUrl=${urlBuilder.apply(fieldSorterAsc.apply('address.suburb'))}"
                     th:onclick="'javascript:onSortChange(\'' + ${newUrl} + '\');'">
                     Suburb
                 </th>
             </thead>
             ...
     </table>

        Supplying a null or empty queryString will return a function accepting the sort field. When this function is fully applied, the new query string will consist of 'sort=field,direction' where 'direction' is derived from the trailing 'Asc' or 'Desc' of the fieldSorterXXX method. All other arguments must receive valid values otherwise the behaviour is undefined.

        Parameters:
        queryString - The current query string.
        Returns:
        Function accepting the field to sort.

      • fieldSorterDesc

        public Function<String,String> fieldSorterDesc​(String queryString)
        See fieldSorterAsc(String) since this method is the same except returns a function capable of sorting a field having a default sort direction of desc.
        Parameters:
        queryString - The current query string.
        Returns:
        Function accepting the field to sort.

      • valueWhenMatchesSortAsc

        public Function<String,String> valueWhenMatchesSortAsc​(String queryString,
                                                       String missingValue,
                                                       String matchingValue,
                                                       String nonMatchingValue)
        This method is useful for conditional css classes or tooltips where different values should be returned based on the current sort direction. A function is returned accepting a single String sort field to avoid having to supply the same values each time when only the sort field will change.

        There are 2 variants of this method valueWhenMatchesSortXXX. The trailing 'Asc' and 'Desc' determines how the equality check is performed as shown below.

        Examples
        Implicit sort direction

        'city' has no direction, using this method with the trailing 'Asc' treats 'city' as having the default direction 'asc' which results in the 'matching' value being returned. 

             #request.getQueryString() = city=melbourne&state=vic&postcode=3000&sort=city

     th:with="value=${#qs.valueWhenMatchesSortAsc(#request.getQueryString(), 'missing', 'matching', 'nonMatching').apply('city')}"
     => value = 'matching'
        Explicit sort direction matches

        Similar to the above example but 'city' has an explicit direction 'asc' which matches the trailing 'Asc' of this method causing the 'matching' value to be returned. If 'city' had direction 'desc' then use valueWhenMatchesSortDesc to have the 'matching' value returned. 

             #request.getQueryString() = city=melbourne&state=vic&postcode=3000&sort=city,asc

     th:with="value=${#qs.valueWhenMatchesSortAsc(#request.getQueryString(), 'missing', 'matching', 'nonMatching').apply('city')}"
     => value = 'matching'
        Explicit sort direction does NOT match

        Similar to the above example but 'city' has an explicit direction 'desc'. Since this method has trailing 'Asc' the equality check is "desc".equals("asc") which is false causing the 'nonMatching' value to be returned. 

             #request.getQueryString() = city=melbourne&state=vic&postcode=3000&sort=city,desc

     th:with="value=${#qs.valueWhenMatchesSortAsc(#request.getQueryString(), 'missing', 'matching', 'nonMatching').apply('city')}"
     => value = 'nonMatching'
        Field not found

        If the field does not appear in the query string under a sort key, the 'missing' value is returned. In this example only 'city' is a sort field but the field supplied is 'country'.

             #request.getQueryString() = city=melbourne&state=vic&postcode=3000&sort=city,desc

     th:with="value=${#qs.valueWhenMatchesSortAsc(#request.getQueryString(), 'missing', 'matching', 'nonMatching').apply('country')}"
     => value = 'missing'
        Complete example

        The final example shows a use case for creating conditional tooltips. The first argument 'Sort hotel name by default direction of ascending', displays how the column will be sorted given no sorting is applied. Otherwise when the 'name' field has a sort direction equal to asc, the tooltip displays the opposite direction of 'Sort hotel name by descending' which is equivalent to the 'matching' value in the above examples.

          
     <table class="ui sortable celled table"
                th:with="qstring=${#request.getQueryString()},
                         cssWhenFieldIsAsc=${#qs.valueWhenMatchesSortAsc(qstring, '', 'sorted ascending', 'sorted descending')}">
             <thead>

             <tr>
                 <th th:classappend="${cssWhenFieldIsAsc.apply('name')}"
                     th:title="${#qs.valueWhenMatchesSortAsc(qstring,
                                  'Sort hotel name by default direction of ascending',
                                  'Sort hotel name descending',
                                  'Sort hotel name ascending')
                                 .apply('name')}">
                     Hotel
                 </th>
             </tr>
             </thead>
             <tbody>
             ...
    </table>

        Supplying a null or empty queryString will return a function that returns the 'missingValue'. All other arguments must receive valid values otherwise the behaviour is undefined.

        Parameters:
        queryString - The current query string.
        missingValue - The value to return if the sort field is not in the query string.
        matchingValue - The value to return if there is a direction match.
        nonMatchingValue - The value to return upon no direction match.
        Returns:
        The function accepting the single String sort field.

      • valueWhenMatchesSortDesc

        public Function<String,String> valueWhenMatchesSortDesc​(String queryString,
                                                        String missingValue,
                                                        String matchingValue,
                                                        String nonMatchingValue)
        The same as valueWhenMatchesSortAsc(String, String, String, String) except applies the opposite logic for 'desc' direction.
        Parameters:
        queryString - The current query string.
        missingValue - The value to return if the sort field is not in the query string.
        matchingValue - The value to return if there is a direction match.
        nonMatchingValue - The value to return upon no direction match.
        Returns:
        The function accepting the single String sort field.

      • createNewSort

        public String createNewSort​(String queryString,
                            List<String> fieldAndDirections)
        Removes all existing sort keys and associates the supplied field and sort direction values to a sort key which gets appended to the end of the query string.
        Thymeleaf Usage

        Notice the new query string only has the new sort field and directions with all previous sorting removed.

             #request.getQueryString() = city=melbourne&postcode=3000&page=0&sort=stars,desc&sort=name

     <h2 th:with="newQueryString=${#qs.createNewSort(#request.getQueryString(), {'city,desc', 'suburb'})}">

     => newQueryString = city=melbourne&postcode=3000&page=0&sort=city,desc&sort=suburb

        If the queryString is null or empty and fieldAndDirections contains values, the new query string will consist of only the new fieldAndDirections, otherwise an empty string will be returned.

        Parameters:
        queryString - The current query string.
        fieldAndDirections - The new sort field and directions such as {'city,desc', 'suburb'}
        Returns:
        The new query string.

      • isFieldSorted

        public boolean isFieldSorted​(String queryString,
                             String field)
        Checks if the supplied field appears as a sort field.
        Thymeleaf Usage
             #request.getQueryString() = city=melbourne&postcode=3000&page=0&sort=city,desc

    <h2 th:with="isSorted=${#qs.isFieldSorted(#request.getQueryString(), 'city')}">
    => isSorted = true

        Supplying a null or empty queryString will return false. All other arguments must receive valid values otherwise the behaviour is undefined.

        Parameters:
        queryString - The current query string.
        field - The sort field.
        Returns:
        true if the field appears as a sort field otherwise false.

      • getCurrentSortDirectionAsc

        public String getCurrentSortDirectionAsc​(String queryString,
                                         String field)
        Extracts the field from the queryString if it appears as a sort field and returns its current sort direction. There are 2 variants of this method getCurrentSortDirectionXXX. The trailing 'Asc' or 'Desc' determines a sort fields default direction should it be missing. A missing sort direction is referred to as an implicit direction which will return 'asc' if getCurrentSortDirectionAsc is being used.
        Thymeleaf Usage
        Sort field has implicit direction

        sort field suburb has no direction so the fallback is to return the default 'asc' if getCurrentSortDirectionAsc is being used.

             #request.getQueryString() = "city=melbourne&postcode=3000&sort=suburb"

     th:with="direction=${#qs.getCurrentSortDirectionAsc(#request.getQueryString(), 'suburb')}"
     => direction = "asc"
        Sort field has explicit direction

        sort field suburb has an explicit sort direction of desc which is returned.

             #request.getQueryString() = "city=melbourne&postcode=3000&sort=suburb,desc"

     th:with="direction=${#qs.getCurrentSortDirectionAsc(#request.getQueryString(), 'suburb')}"
     => direction = "desc"
        Sort field does not exist

        sort field country does not exist so null is returned

             #request.getQueryString() = #request.getQueryString() = "city=melbourne&postcode=3000&sort=suburb"

     th:with="direction=${#qs.getCurrentSortDirectionAsc(#request.getQueryString(), 'country')}"
     => direction = null
        Sort field is a nested object

        Consider a Person containing an Address. For example, use the property path to access the sort field 'address.suburb'. This assumes the Person is in the Model.

             #request.getQueryString() = "city=melbourne&postcode=3000&sort=address.suburb,desc"

     th:with="direction=${#qs.getCurrentSortDirectionAsc(#request.getQueryString(), 'address.suburb')}"
     => direction = "desc"

        Supplying a null or empty queryString will return null. All other arguments must receive valid values otherwise the behaviour is undefined.

        Parameters:
        queryString - The current query string.
        field - The sort field to find the sort direction for.
        Returns:
        The sort direction of either asc | desc if found, otherwise null.

      • getCurrentSortDirectionDesc

        public String getCurrentSortDirectionDesc​(String queryString,
                                          String field)
        The same as getCurrentSortDirectionAsc(String, String) except this method uses desc as the fallback when the sort field contains no explicit sort direction.
        Parameters:
        queryString - The current query string.
        field - The sort field to find the sort direction for.
        Returns:
        The sort direction of either asc | desc if found, otherwise null.

      • url

        public String url​(String requestURI,
                  String queryString)
        Concatenates the request uri with the query string should it exist. The motivation for this method is to provide a solution for restrictions preventing methods receiving the HttpServletRequest directly via the #request object in Thymeleaf 3.0.9. http://forum.thymeleaf.org/Thymeleaf-3-0-9-JUST-PUBLISHED-td4030728.html

        Since each method cannot accept a #request, its recommended to assign the query string to a new variable before proceeding to rebuild the complete URI. To avoid having to supply #request.getRequestURI() each time, use urlBuilder(String).

        Thymeleaf usage
             th:with="newQueryString=${#qs.incrementPage(#request.getQueryString())}"
     th:href="${#qs.url(#request.getRequestURI(), newQueryString)}"

        Supplying a null or empty requestURI throws an IllegalArgumentException. If the queryString is present it will be concatenated to the requestURI.

        Parameters:
        requestURI - The result of calling #request.getRequestURI().
        queryString - The current query string.
        Returns:
        The new url.

      • urlBuilder

        public Function<String,String> urlBuilder​(String requestURI)
        See url(String, String) for docs as this method is provided out of convenience to clean up thymeleaf template code to avoid having to supply the #request.getRequestURI() each time.

        This method is a curried function accepting the requestURI and returns a function that accepts the queryString which concatenates the 2 together. The below example shows the urlBuilder being defined as a variable for reuse in every table header without needing to supply the requestURI each time.

        Thymeleaf Usage
             
     <table class="ui sortable celled table"
                th:with="qstring=${#request.getQueryString()},
                         urlBuilder=${#qs.urlBuilder(#request.getRequestURI())},
                         fieldSorterAsc=${#qs.fieldSorterAsc(qstring)}">
             <thead>

             <tr>
                 <th th:with="newUrl=${urlBuilder.apply(fieldSorterAsc.apply('name'))}">
                     Hotel
                 </th>
              </tr>
              ....
              </thead>
    </table>
        Parameters:
        requestURI - The result of #request.getRequestURI()
        Returns:
        The new url.
